title: Trump Denounces Russia 'Bounty' Intelligence as Hoax
summary: President blames newspapers, Democrats for the assessment that Russia paid the Taliban to target American soldiers. President Trump denounced as "a hoax" reports that Russia paid bounties for attacks on American soldiers, while administration officials said he may yet pursue talks with Moscow through international organizations such as the Group of Seven leading nations.

title: Seattle Police Dismantle 'Police-Free Zone'
summary: The move aims to end a three-week standoff between officers and protesters in the area known as CHOP. Seattle police on Wednesday dismantled the self-styled Capitol Hill Organized Protest area, ending a three-week standoff between officers and protesters who had declared it a police-free zone.

title: FAA's Handling of Boeing 737 MAX Issues Faulted in Review
summary: Sluggish response, lack of urgency contributed to second deadly crash, inspector general indicates. Safety fixes after the first Boeing Co . 737 MAX crash became snarled in Federal Aviation Administration delays and repetitive analyses, wasting any chance U.S. regulators had to prevent the second fatal accident, according to an investigation by the Transportation Department's internal watchdog.

title: The Coronavirus Credibility Gap
summary: Politicians and experts sow distrust with double standards on protests and dissembling about masks.. The American public is fractured over policy responses to Covid-19. That rift is most visible in debates about masks and new rounds of shutdowns. Such disputes are common in a country as diverse and opinionated as America. But political leaders and health officials have sown distrust by politicizing the pandemic response.

title: The Meaning of Hong Kong
summary: China snuffs out a beacon of freedom, a warning to the world.. China's decision to impose its national-security law on Hong Kong is a seismic event that goes well beyond the sad fate of its 7.5 million people. The illegal takeover shows that Beijing's Communist rulers are willing to violate their international commitments with impunity as they spread their authoritarian model.

title: Sheldon Whitehouse's Favors
summary: The Senator intervened for a company after campaign cash flowed.. Rhode Island Senator Sheldon Whitehouse makes a habit of accusing his opponents of corruption. So let's take a look at an example of the Senator's political mediation that Mr. Whitehouse would surely denounce if the facts involved someone he disliked.

title: The Green New Deal in Action
summary: Democrats kill a child-labor measure for green-energy minerals.. House Transportation Committee Chairman Peter DeFazio hailed the $1.5 trillion infrastructure spending bill that House Democrats passed on Wednesday as "the application of the principles of the Green New Deal." Ok, then, let's see what's inside the party pack.

title: Hotel San Francisco
summary: A pair of lawsuits highlight the decline of public order.. San Francisco was the first U.S. city to lock down and strictly enforce its shelter-in-place order-at least against law-abiding citizens. Meanwhile, public officials and police let hundreds of the homeless crowd streets and use drugs in the downtown Tenderloin district, according to two new lawsuits against the city.

title: U.S. Warns CEOs Over Supply Chains Tied to Rights Violations in China
summary: 'CEOs should read this notice closely,' Secretary of State Mike Pompeo says. WASHINGTON-The U.S. warned companies that have suppliers or customers in China of legal and reputational risks linked to human-rights violations there, part of the Trump administration's broader effort to limit business ties with the country.

title: House Passes Extension of Paycheck Protection Program
summary: Aid effort for small businesses extended to Aug. 8; Senate already approved, bill heads to President Trump. The House of Representatives passed a bill Wednesday extending the timeline into next month for small businesses to apply for forgivable loans, building on a surprise vote in the Senate a day earlier.

title: Building Collapses in Brooklyn
summary: The three-story Carroll Gardens building, which housed a gym, had 16 open violations. A three-story building collapsed Wednesday afternoon in the Carroll Gardens section of Brooklyn.

title: The Trump Campaign Needs to Hit 'Reset'
summary: If the president won't offer voters an agenda for his second term, he may not get one.. It's Team Trump's time in the barrel. After the underwhelming crowd in Tulsa, Okla., and polls showing the president trailing Joe Biden substantially, the political commentariat is beginning to say Mr. Trump has no chance of re-election.

title: Strike Up the Banned
summary: The Chicks renounce Dixie. But 'David L. Roth' won't say if his change is on the level.. What do Woodrow Wilson and the Dixie Chicks have in common? This week Princeton University announced it will remove the 28th president's name from its School of Public and International Affairs, in a rebuke to his "racist thinking and policies."

title: You Say You Want a Revolution?
summary: The benchmark for American revolt remains the Declaration of Independence signed on July 4, 1776.. They can take down Teddy Roosevelt, and Princeton can cancel Woodrow Wilson. They can topple Ulysses Grant, deface the Lincoln Memorial, throw ropes around Andrew Jackson in Lafayette Square, knock down the author of "The Star-Spangled Banner," put Thomas Jefferson in storage, and say America's founding began in 1619. But they can't make the Fourth of July disappear.

title: Notable & Quotable: Pew Poll
summary: 'Fewer voters (28%) say Biden would be a good or great president than say that about Trump as president.'. From a June 30 report by the Pew Research Center:

title: 'The World' Review: The Old New World Order
summary: America's young elites are uninformed and incurious about world affairs. This dry-as-dust primer isn't going to help change that.. Richard Haass is a prolific author on international affairs, served as a foreign-policy official in the Reagan and both Bush administrations, and is now president of the Council on Foreign Relations. He is, in short, a high-ranking member of American foreign policy's clerisy. As if to emphasize the point, he relates that the inspiration for his book "The World: A Brief Introduction" began with a day of fishing in Nantucket, where he spoke with a student from Stanford who confessed that he had taken few courses in economics, politics or history. Otherwise educated young people today, Mr. Haass concludes, "are essentially uninformed about the world they are entering." He hopes to change this state of affairs with "The World."

title: Richmond Mayor Orders Removal of Confederate Statues
summary: About a dozen monuments to be hauled away in coming days. Richmond's mayor on Wednesday used emergency powers to order the immediate removal of about a dozen Confederate statues, citing public safety concerns and a need for healing in a city still grappling with its legacy as the capital of the Confederacy during the Civil War.

title: AIG and Barings Among Lenders Objecting to Hertz Fleet Cuts
summary: Capital Group, One William Street Capital are part of a creditor group saying car-rental company can't cherry-pick cars it wants to keep. Capital Group Cos., Barings LLC and One William Street Capital Management LP are among the asset-backed securities lenders fighting Hertz Global Holdings Inc.'s plan to reduce its U.S. rental fleet by more than a fourth.

title: Antitrust Enforcers Update Approach to Vertical Mergers
summary: New guidance spells out how authorities assess whether combinations within a supply chain could harm competition. The U.S. issued new guidance on how authorities assess whether mergers within a supply chain might affect competition-an update that could have implications for federal antitrust enforcers' focus on the technology sector.

title: Trump Threatens to Veto Defense Bill to Preserve Confederate Base Names
summary: Amendment to rename military bases passed in bipartisan vote; president's veto threat draws chilly response from GOP lawmakers. WASHINGTON-President Trump threatened to veto an annual must-pass bill if senators don't remove language that would require the Defense Department to rename U.S. military bases that honor the Confederacy, but his demand drew a chilly reception from Republican lawmakers.

title: Coney Island Emerges From Lockdown as New York City Beaches Reopen
summary: Even without the rides, beachgoers arrive and businesses adapt to the new normal. So far, it has been a summer of disappointment and frustration at Coney Island, the historic Brooklyn beachside amusement area that is largely shut because of the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Fed Debated Options to Provide More Economic Support
summary: Minutes show officials grappled with extreme uncertainty and changes in economic conditions when they met June 9-10. Federal Reserve officials last month reviewed how to design more support for an economy reeling from the coronavirus pandemic while expressing concerns over the risks of additional virus outbreaks.

title: McDonald's Halts Reopening Plans as U.S. Coronavirus Cases Grow
summary: Burger chain is suspending additional dine-in service ahead of holiday weekend. McDonald's Corp. is pausing the reopening of dine-in service in the U.S. as coronavirus cases continue to spread across states.

title: House Passes $1.5 Trillion Infrastructure Bill
summary: Democratic plan to rebuild roads and rails doesn't have Republican support, and bipartisan efforts have faltered for years. WASHINGTON-The House passed a broad, $1.5 trillion effort to rebuild the nation's roads, railways and schools, as Democrats pursued their own infrastructure legislation without the bipartisan deal discussed for years during the Trump administration.

title: Coronavirus Politics Fueled Challenger in Colo. House GOP Primary
summary: Lauren Boebert defeated Rep. Scott Tipton on Tuesday night, winning by about 9 percentage points. Pandemic-related politics helped propel a gun-toting restaurateur to an upset win against a five-term Republican congressman in a Colorado primary, underlining the unpredictability the coronavirus outbreak is injecting into elections this year.

title: Hedge Fund Star John Paulson Calls It Quits
summary: Mr. Paulson's decision had been telegraphed as assets at his firm fell and returns declined. John Paulson made billions of dollars anticipating the 2008 financial collapse. But after running into difficulties in recent years, Mr. Paulson will convert his hedge fund firm into a private investment firm that runs only his family's money.

title: On the Whole, Cuomo's Managed Covid Well
summary: Gov. Cuomo was the only one giving me daily, dispassionate and helpful advice along with easy-to-understand graphs and statistics.. Regarding your editorial "Cuomo's Covid Chutzpah" (June 27): The ordering of the quarantine for individuals coming from "hot spot" states for Covid-19 by the governors of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut wasn't the first such order of its kind and probably won't be the last ordered by state governors. In defense of Gov. Andrew Cuomo, the New York State Department of Health's nursing-home directive of March 25 regarding the return of their residents from hospitals was a decision forced by the rapidly overwhelming demand for hospital space in New York for seriously ill patients at a time of evolving guidance regarding the management of these residents. The unfortunate result was a hard lesson learned by all. With the current spike in diagnosed cases and hospitalizations in many states and with the management of the pandemic in the hands of governors and mayors, the Journal needs to target the real issue: the continuing lack of accountable, well-informed, decisive science-based leadership at the highest federal level. If this abdication of responsible leadership continues, one wonders what the relatives and friends of the thousands of individuals who may have needlessly succumbed to this pandemic will be doing in November.

title: Pizza Hut and Wendy's Franchisee NPC Files for Bankruptcy
summary: The biggest Pizza Hut and Wendy's franchise operator in the U.S. was struggling before the coronavirus pandemic. NPC International Inc., the nation's largest Pizza Hut and Wendy's franchisee, filed for bankruptcy Wednesday and will put its burger restaurants up for sale as it continues to hold discussions over the fate of its pizza outlets.

title: College Degrees, Race and Better-Paid Jobs
summary: Requiring a particular degree provided a low-cost employment application-filtration system that eliminated the need to hire extra human-resources staff.. Peter Q. Blair and Shad Ahmed make a good point about the need to focus on required job skills rather than emphasizing college degrees as a condition of employment ("The Disparate Racial Impact of Requiring a College Degree," op-ed, June 29). Leave aside the fact that many high schools today don't prepare students for even the fundamental three Rs they'll need to function as productive adults.

title: Honor the Flawed Humans Who've Repented, Changed
summary: The Biblical narratives portray their characters as real, flawed human beings, who can find redemption despite their flaws-and that is often the lesson we're meant to learn.. Regarding Cardinal Timothy Dolan's "Even the Bible Is Full of Flawed Characters" (op-ed, June 29): Archbishop Dolan misses a key point about monuments and narratives. The Biblical narratives portray their characters as real, flawed human beings who can find redemption despite their flaws-and that is often the lesson we're meant to learn. A heroic statue of a Confederate officer in a public space does no such thing. It's not "history," it's propaganda. It's a narrative people who care about faith and history should want to correct.

title: Specialty Lenders Face Funding Challenge
summary: Firms have raised money by selling shares at discounted prices and issuing bonds at high interest rates. Some specialty finance companies that lend to midsize businesses are confronting the threat of a funding squeeze just as the coronavirus pandemic is causing defaults to rise, a potential one-two punch that could curtail their activities.

title: How Success Against the Coronavirus Turned to Crisis in California
summary: While the state controlled the shutdown, reopenings were left to counties, resulting in inconsistent policies; 'The virus doesn't stay within a boundary'.

title: Songs for a Summer of Solitude
summary: Concerts may be canceled and parties put on hold, but there's still plenty of outstanding new music to fill a seasonal playlist..

title: China Erodes Media Freedoms in Hong Kong
summary: Beijing's tighter control spreads unease in what has been a vibrant press hub. In a new era of tighter Chinese government control of Hong Kong, the city is likely to see the sun set on broad media freedoms.

title: S&P 500 Edges Up to Start Third Quarter
summary: A private employment report signaled continued healing in the U.S. job market. The S&P 500 rose in the first session of July after data showed the labor market continued to improve last month.

title: How to Plan Your Budget With Just One Income
summary: Some couples may have to adjust to living on one salary due to pandemic-related job losses. Here's what you can do now.. Generally, if someone was working for a company and lost a job through no fault of their own, they will likely qualify. Apply as soon as possible, because it could take some time to start receiving benefits.

title: Macy's Says Most Stores Have Reopened
summary: The department-store chain warns it could tighten safety restrictions on a regional level. Macy's Inc. said nearly all its stores have reopened after a monthslong closure due to the Covid-19 pandemic, though the retailer warned it could take other measures as states tally more coronavirus infections.

title: Flying Through the Pandemic With the New United CEO
summary: Scott Kirby took over the airline six weeks ago with coronavirus halting most travel-what he does next will help shape what fliers experience for years to come. There's rarely an easy time to become chief executive of an airline, in an industry with near-constant turbulence. Try doing it during a pandemic.

title: Apple to Shut Dozens of Stores as Coronavirus Flares
summary: Company has been reopening locations, but now reverses course in some areas. Apple Inc. is temporarily closing dozens of stores in states around the country as the Covid-19 pandemic has worsened in certain regions.

title: New York City Delays Indoor Dining Indefinitely
summary: Postponement due to rising coronavirus cases in other states and lack of social distancing by locals. Struggling New York City bars and restaurants were dealt a blow Wednesday as officials delayed the start of indoor dining, citing concerns about the spread of the coronavirus.

title: The Staying Inside Guide: Infinitely Interpretable
summary: The Great American Songbook's flexibility has long made it a source for musicians to return to in search of inspiration.. The Great American Songbook has one definitive virtue: flexibility. For example, an Irving Berlin song like "Blue Skies" can be reconfigured rhythmically as a waltz, a polka, or a bossa nova, sound happy or sad. Appropriately, the leading interpreters of the songbook tend to place great emphasis on spontaneity and something akin to improvisation.

title: Wirecard Administrators to Sell Assets as Investigators Search Offices
summary: Prosecutors and police search company's headquarters as administrators step up efforts to find new investors. Bankruptcy administrators for Wirecard AG, the scandal-hit German payments company, have begun the process of selling some of its businesses, as they try to stabilize its operations and raise money to pay off its heavy debt burden.

title: SoftBank Seeks to End Partnership With Wirecard
summary: Japanese tech conglomerate looks to distance itself after it helped arrange a $1 billion investment. SoftBank Group Corp. is looking to distance itself from Wirecard AG, after the Japanese tech conglomerate helped arrange a $1 billion investment months before the German payments company went bust.

title: New York City Considers Testing Sewage for Coronavirus
summary: Analysis of wastewater could serve as an early detection system and get ahead of outbreaks. New York City residents produce more than a billion gallons of sewage a day and nearly every toilet is connected to the public sewer system. That wastewater tells a story about the health of the city, and officials are hoping to use it as a new way to monitor the spread of the novel coronavirus.

title: Abuse Victims Suspect Boy Scouts Councils of Moving Assets Out of Reach
summary: Most of the Boy Scouts' wealth is in the hands of local councils, some of which are putting property up for sale. Lawyers for men claiming they were sexually abused by Boy Scouts of America volunteers as children said they suspect some local councils of the youth organization are moving assets out of their reach.

title: Ghosn's Escape From Japan Leaves Seven Facing Trial in Turkey
summary: An airline manager, four pilots and two flight attendants are expected to stand trial on Friday. ISTANBUL-Seven Turkish defendants are due to stand trial here on Friday in what will be the first court examination of how one-time auto titan Carlos Ghosn used Turkey as a steppingstone late last year to reach Lebanon after fleeing Japan inside a musical equipment box.

title: A Recovery That Started Out Like a V Is Changing Shape
summary: A resurgence of coronavirus cases is making the rebound look more like the reverse image of the square root symbol. After recovering rapidly from mid-April through mid-June the economy has shown signs of sputtering in the past two weeks.

title: Supreme Court's DACA Decision Leaves These Young Immigrants in Limbo
summary: Resume Subscription. The Covid-19 pandemic has put many people's lives on hold, disrupting their planning for the future. This kind of limbo has long been a way of life for the more than 650,000 young immigrants who have been temporarily protected from deportation under the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals, or DACA, program. These young immigrants were brought to the U.S. as children, and some lack direct ties to their homeland. When the Supreme Court ruled earlier this month that President Trump could not eliminate the program without offering a better rationale, DACA recipients were jubilant. But they remain in a state of uncertainty....

title: Russians Vote for Overhaul That Could Keep Putin in Power Until 2036
summary: Overwhelming preliminary results point to the biggest constitutional shake-up since the end of the Soviet Union. MOSCOW-Russians voted overwhelmingly to change their country's constitution, paving the way for President Vladimir Putin to remain in power and chart Russia's destiny for years to come.

title: Global Manufacturing Shows Fresh Signs of Recovery
summary: In some countries, including France and the U.K., manufacturing sectors return to growth. Factory activity around the world showed further signs of recovery in June as governments eased restrictions designed to contain the coronavirus, but weak demand still weighed on production and employment, according to surveys of purchasing managers.

title: Car Sales Fell in the Second Quarter, Despite Deals and Covid-19 Stimulus
summary: The industry is facing a test this summer as deals dry up and the impact of federal aid fades. Major auto makers reported sharp drops in second-quarter U.S. vehicle sales, as sweet discounts and financing deals weren't enough to offset factory and dealership closures from the Covid-19 pandemic.

title: ViacomCBS Names Amazon Executive as Its New Finance Chief
summary: Naveen Chopra will take over from CFO Christina Spade less than a year after ViacomCBS merger. ViacomCBS Inc. plans to replace its finance chief less than a year after closing a major merger, as the media company navigates a challenging business environment.

title: Semper Investment Firm Received PPP Loan
summary: Firm owned by Richard Parsons and Ronald Lauder received a $726,200 loan in April from government program. A $2.5 billion investment firm owned by Richard Parsons and Ronald Lauder received a forgivable loan from the federal government's small business loan program, even as many small businesses say the terms made it impossible for them to qualify.

title: USMCA Takes Effect but Trade Tensions Remain
summary: Nafta's replacement, a Trump administration priority, kicks in after years of negotiation even as certain matters have emerged to complicate its rollout. WASHINGTON-The U.S.-Mexico-Canada Agreement kicks in Wednesday, but the culmination of years of negotiations won't necessarily mean the end of trade tensions among the three North American nations.

title: Young Voters Are Getting Behind Joe Biden
summary: Protests against police brutality and racial injustice are driving some momentum. The presumptive Democratic nominee has widened his lead over President Trump with younger voters, gaining among the demographic even as some want to see the Biden campaign back bigger changes to law enforcement.

title: More Homeowners Are Playing the Name Game
summary: The practice of naming properties persists, as people put their own stamp on even historical estates. William F. Whitman's ancestors, two Fifield brothers, staked a claim around Burnt Cove in Stonington, Maine, in 1801, following the end of the Revolutionary and the French and Indian wars when the remote island outpost became safe to settle, according to family lore.

title: Oil Prices Climb After Inventory Data
summary: Prices are near highest level since early March, buoyed by recovering fuel demand and supply cuts by OPEC, allies. Oil prices rose Wednesday, continuing a recent rebound after data showed U.S. crude stockpiles fell more than anticipated last week.

title: Green Bonds Need the Right Filter
summary: The industry must not let its impressive growth undermine essential efforts to standardize what counts as green. Green bonds are attracting a growing army of well-intentioned sponsors, certifiers and investors. They need to be careful not to let their own agendas undermine the market's success.

title: U.S. Treasury to Lend $700 Million to Trucking Firm YRC
summary: Government will take a 29.6% equity stake in the company, Treasury says. WASHINGTON-The U.S. government plans to lend $700 million in coronavirus stimulus funds to trucking firm YRC Worldwide Inc . , in exchange for a 29.6% equity stake in the company, the Treasury Department said Wednesday.

title: Germany to Shake Up Special-Forces Unit Harboring Far-Right Militants
summary: One company in elite group will be disbanded, others subjected to new training regime. BERLIN-Germany will disband part of its elite special-forces unit and rebuild the rest under new leadership after the commandos were infiltrated by far-right militants, the government said on Wednesday.

title: Netanyahu Needs to Slice the Annexation Salami
summary: His base is more useful to him hungry, and Israel's neighbors and allies can't stomach a full meal of it.. The Israeli cabinet is scheduled to begin discussions this week on the possible unilateral annexation of Israeli settlements in the West Bank along with strategically important roadways and the Jordan Valley. While anything is possible in the tumultuous world of Israeli politics, what changes come are likely to be modest and incremental-more like slicing a salami than swallowing large new additions in a huge gulp.

title: Price Controls Would Throttle Biomedical Innovation
summary: Congress should reject legislation that would deprive startups of vital investment capital.. The speed with which biomedical researchers have raced to develop vaccines and find treatments for the novel coronavirus has been breathtaking. Across the world, nearly 400 unique therapies are under investigation. Fourteen vaccines are in clinical trials. If we're lucky, one or more will prove safe and effective, paving the way for widespread inoculation against Covid-19.

title: Historic Coast Guard Ship 'Taney' to Be Renamed
summary: Last U.S. warship afloat from Pearl Harbor attack drew protests for honoring Supreme Court chief justice who delivered Dred Scott decision. The historic Coast Guard cutter the "Taney" will be renamed as soon as possible so that it no longer pays tribute to the antebellum Supreme Court chief justice who delivered the Dred Scott decision, according to a Baltimore museum in charge of the ship.

title: Nile Niami Is L.A.'s Megamansion King. Has He Built a House of Cards?
summary: Resume Subscription. Standing on a grassy knoll in a tightfitting V-neck T-shirt and gold-rimmed aviators, views of the Los Angeles basin and a cluster of sunbathing women sprawled out behind him, developer Nile Niami looked every bit the king of the city's megamansion scene.

title: Junk Bonds Underperform as Covid Cases Climb
summary: Pimco favors investment-grade and MBS over high yield. Worry about a second wave of Covid-19 cases is pushing junk bond yields to their highest levels in a month, causing the risky debt to underperform other credit markets.

title: Saudis Threaten New Oil-Price War With OPEC Brethren
summary: As major producers look to curb output, the kingdom takes a tough stance with laggards. Saudi Arabia has threatened to ignite an oil-price war unless fellow OPEC members make up for their failure to abide by the cartel's recent production cuts, delegates said.

title: General Mills Expects High Demand for Soup, Baking Mixes to Continue
summary: Food maker says coronavirus-related lockdowns and financial pressure are driving sales growth. General Mills Inc. is the latest food maker to benefit from unprecedented demand for long-lasting items such as soup and cereal amid the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Coca-Cola to Close Odwalla Juice Business
summary: Move follows yearslong review of business's performance and will lead to elimination of about 300 jobs. Coca-Cola Co. is discontinuing its Odwalla juice business and a refrigerated trucking network that delivered fresh drinks to stores, the latest sign of consumer-goods companies narrowing their focus during the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Fed's Daly: If Coronavirus Contained, Economy Could Recover Quickly
summary: San Francisco Fed president says economic data should be collected before making judgments and deciding what else might be needed. Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco President Mary Daly said Wednesday that while uncertainty faces the economy right now, a successful containment of the coronavirus pandemic would be very positive for the economy.

title: Macy's Stores: Burden or Savior?
summary: The department-store chain's physical locations are in trouble, but they are also saving the company. Bricks-and-mortar retail might be a sinking ship, but it is also Macy's life vest-for now.

title: John Bolton Memoir Sells Over 780,000 Copies in First Week
summary: Former national security adviser's book joins a list of hot-selling political titles. Former national security adviser John Bolton's memoir sold more than 780,000 copies in all formats through its first week on sale in the U.S., publisher Simon & Schuster said Wednesday, the latest strong performance for a political book.

title: Coronavirus Vaccine Candidate From Pfizer, BioNTech Produces Positive Results
summary: Those getting experimental vaccine had higher levels of antibodies compared with recovered Covid-19 patients, researchers say. Researchers said an experimental coronavirus vaccine from Pfizer Inc. and partner BioNTech SE showed promising signs of working in an early-stage study.

title: No, Really, Your Boss Wants You to Take Vacation-Now
summary: Call it a summer standoff: Companies want people to take vacation time, but with travel plans on hold, employees are hoarding days off. Companies' latest memo to workers: Take a vacation already!

summary: Sometimes it's hard to remember what subscriptions you have and which one has which content. It's been well over a decade since Netflix launched its first streaming service. For some, the years have begun to seem longer.

summary: Merchants have seen a lot of browsing by John Smith, who picks up items, then leaves without buying; 'it started getting out of hand'. John Smith started shopping early on a recent Wednesday and didn't stop for days.

title: Coronavirus Relief Runs Out for Cash-Strapped Internet Customers
summary: Wireless and broadband companies that offered coronavirus relief on bills for pandemic-affected customers can start charging again. The relief came with an expiration date: July 1.

title: Inside Moderna: The Covid Vaccine Front-Runner With No Track Record and an Unsparing CEO

summary: Plus, four more films and series about America's founding to add to your queue for the Fourth of July. title: Twitter's Voice Tweets Upset Users Again Over Accessibility
summary: Tech companies emphasize speed in new products at the expense of accessibility, advocates say. They also said it is the sort of problem that happens a lot in technology.

title: Three Months In, These Patients Are Still Ravaged by Covid's Fallout

title: Protests Against Racism Struggle to Gain Traction in Italy
summary: Activists say Italy is missing a golden opportunity to confront the problems faced by its minorities. ROME-Many Western countries are debating their present and past records on racial inequality following the killing of George Floyd. title: FedEx Delivers Through the Crisis
summary: FedEx's decision to focus on servicing e-commerce merchants such as Walmart is looking prescient. FedEx 's decision to embrace e-commerce orders may have had its doubters, but in a world gripped by the Covid-19 crisis, it is looking exactly right.

title: TuSimple Adds Logistics Operators to Self-Driving Trucks Effort

title: The More Markets Change, the More They Stay the Same
summary: Covid-19 crisis has roiled markets, yet six months into 2020 the big financial trends seem remarkably familiar. The Covid-19 crisis has shaken politics and economics with the power of an asteroid hitting Earth. When it comes to financial markets, though, it is more of a pebble.

title: Biden Gains Support With Young Voters Amid Protests
summary: Activists voice urgent desire to defeat President Trump but dissatisfaction with Democratic candidate's plans to address racial bias in policing. title: Fed's $600 Billion Main Street Lending Program Sees Lukewarm Interest
summary: Bankers say firms most in need of aid won't qualify, while strong firms can find better terms elsewhere. WASHINGTON-The government is offering to lend up to $600 billion to help small and midsize businesses weather the coronavirus-induced recession, but so far interest has been sparse.

title: How Chloe x Halle Turned Their Tennis Court Into An Award Show Arena
summary: How the young R&B duo crafted performances during isolation that are a lot grander than just singing into a webcam. For BET's first virtual awards show this weekend, Chloe and Halle Bailey performed in a haunted jungle lair before appearing in different costumes and moving to a candy-apple set that made it look as if they had been transported to an old TLC video from the '90s.

title: Japan's Passenger Jet Project in Trouble After $4.9 Billion Loss
summary: Coronavirus adds to woes of Mitsubishi Aircraft's SpaceJet, already delayed six times. TOKYO-Mitsubishi Aircraft Corp. reported an annual loss of $4.9 billion, the latest distress signal in a turbulent decadelong quest to build Japan's first passenger jet.

title: Trump Campaign Reassigns Chief Operating Officer After Tulsa Rally
summary: Jeff DeWit, an Arizona businessman and longtime Trump ally, will succeed Michael Glassner, who will oversee legal issues. President Trump's campaign is making a senior leadership change, moving Michael Glassner from chief operating officer into a role overseeing legal issues.

title: Bank Fraud Allegations Test Marijuana Business
summary: Prosecutors allege scheme to disguise $100 million in cannabis product sales in a case that could have implications for industry. On March 9, a German businessman named Ruben Weigand was arrested at Los Angeles International Airport, during a layover on his way to Costa Rica. In an indictment unsealed later that week, federal prosecutors in Manhattan charged Mr. Weigand with a single count of conspiracy to commit bank fraud, stemming from an alleged scheme to trick banks into processing more than $100 million in marijuana sales.

title: When Companies Prepare for Disaster, Investors Should Expect Lower Returns
summary: Coronavirus crisis is leading companies to go from 'just in time' to 'just in case'. Investors who want to look beyond the day-to-day concerns of second lockdowns and the shape of economic recoveries should focus on one word: Resilience.

title: The Sports Restart Has a Plan for Everything-Except a Coronavirus Outbreak
summary: Leagues have hundreds of pages of health and safety protocols. But the great unknown of the sports comeback is what they'll do if the virus spreads within a team or the league.. The attempted returns of Major League Baseball and the NBA will be governed by more than 200 pages of health and safety protocols that cover just about everything imaginable.

title: A Top Employer of M.B.A.s Creates a Degree of Its Own
summary: Ernst & Young works with a business school to offer a part-time, online program that is free for employees. Accounting and advisory firm EY, one of the top employers of M.B.A. graduates each year, is now handing out its own degree.

title: If Your Colleague Has Covid-19, Will Your Employer Tell You?
summary: With few rules, companies set their own guidelines on who finds out about an infection; 'Please get tested if you know me'. With more workers back on the job, companies from clothing retailers to auto makers are increasingly confronting a difficult question: If an employee tests positive for Covid-19, who should be told?

title: Months Into Pandemic, ICU Doctors Are Split on Best Treatment
summary: Medical debate focuses on whether established treatment protocols for respiratory distress are helping or harming Covid-19 patients. Several months into the coronavirus pandemic, hospital physicians are split on whether long-established treatment protocols for patients in respiratory distress are helping or harming patients with Covid-19.

title: Hickenlooper Wins Colorado Democratic Senate Primary
summary: Former governor will face Republican incumbent Sen. Cory Gardner in November. Former Colorado Gov. John Hickenlooper won the Democratic Senate primary Tuesday night, setting up a high-profile contest this fall with incumbent Republican Sen. Cory Gardner as Democrats try to win control of the Senate.

title: Immigration Agency Plans to Furlough Staff, Suspend Services Absent a Bailout From Congress
summary: Talks over USCIS's request for $1.2 billion in emergency money remain far from resolved. WASHINGTON-U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services, the agency that oversees legal immigration, is sending furlough notices to about 69% of its staff and preparing to suspend services in August because Congress and the Trump administration can't agree on terms of a $1.2 billion infusion.

title: Social Distancing Gives Motorbike Makers a Smoother Ride
summary: Consumers are turning to two-wheelers to keep them away from public transport, but Hondas may benefit more than Harleys. This recession might be a surprisingly good one for motorbike and motorcycle manufacturers-with the likely exception of Harley-Davidson.

title: Chinese Oil Futures Draw More International Interest
summary: Higher trading volumes and relative stability of Chinese oil prices this year have helped increase global appetite. Foreign companies and investors are warming to Chinese oil futures, a boost to a project that Beijing hopes will boost the yuan's appeal and loosen the dollar's hold on global commodity pricing.

title: Movie Theaters Get a Painful Extended Intermission
summary: Resurgence of coronavirus pandemic has thwarted reopening plans and keeps release slate in flux. Even the most dedicated moviegoers, willing to wear masks, need something to actually see.

title: Your Child Will Be Ready Soon: Day Cares and Other Businesses Use Restaurant-Style Tech to Fight Long Lines
summary: Virtual queues can relieve the tedium of wait times extended by social distancing. No one likes queueing in the best of times, but coronavirus has made it worse than ever. There's more of it, as capacity limits for stores and other venues create waits to get inside. Lines stretch further, as social distancing forces bigger gaps between the people waiting. And lingering next to the same people for long periods can feel like a health risk.

title: Some New Yorkers Had Coronavirus Antibodies in February, Study Shows
summary: Virus may have been introduced into New York City region earlier than previously thought, researchers say. Some New Yorkers had antibodies for the new coronavirus more than a week before the first official case in the state was announced on March 1, new research shows.

title: How Minneapolis Left a Police Station to Rioters
summary: Resume Subscription. MINNEAPOLIS-Police were preparing another round of tear gas to use against a rock-throwing crowd when they got word from Mayor Jacob Frey on the night of Thursday, May 28, to abandon the city's Third Precinct, the station where the four officers charged in the killing of George Floyd had worked.

title: Australia Lays Out China-Focused Defense Overhaul
summary: Country seeks to create a larger, more powerful force focused on the Indo-Pacific, to counterbalance Beijing's increasingly muscular stance in the region. SYDNEY-Australia is overhauling its military to create a larger, more powerful force focused on the Indo-Pacific as it seeks to counterbalance China's growing influence and military power in the region.

title: New York City Leaders Approve Austere Budget, Police Cuts
summary: The $88.19 billion budget shifts $1 billion in funding from the NYPD to youth and social services. Mayor Bill de Blasio and the New York City Council on Tuesday approved an $88.19 billion budget for the coming fiscal year that drastically cuts city spending while shifting nearly $1 billion in funding from the New York Police Department to youth and social services.

title: Hot Pandemic Market: Music Royalties
summary: Unable to tour, artists tap their catalogs for income as music rights increasingly are seen as 'a sound alternative asset'. When Sonia Leigh's tour dates were canceled this spring, erasing much of her expected income, the Nashville singer-songwriter looked to leverage one of her most valuable commodities: her songs.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Investors to Food Companies: What Have You Done for Us Lately?
summary: Following a sales surge in the spring, food companies must brace for a return to normal. Packaged-food companies have benefited hugely from the coronavirus crisis. But investors have already turned their attention to what comes next.

title: New York Judge Blocks Publication of Tell-All Book by Trump's Niece
summary: Lawyers for Mary Trump and Simon & Schuster plan to appeal, calling decision violation of First Amendment. A New York judge granted President Trump's younger brother, Robert S. Trump, a temporary injunction Tuesday delaying the publication of a tell-all book by the president's niece.

title: Coronavirus Sends Oil Prices on Wild, Six-Month Ride
summary: U.S. crude's 92% advance marks oil's largest quarterly percentage gain in 30 years. The coronavirus transformed global oil markets in the first half of 2020, sending prices on a wild ride and spurring historic changes to energy supply chains and products used to invest in crude.

title: Aeroméxico Files for Chapter 11 Bankruptcy Protection
summary: Mexican airline says it will continue operating during restructuring. MEXICO CITY-Mexican airline company Grupo Aeroméxico SAB filed Tuesday for voluntary restructuring under chapter 11 of the U.S. bankruptcy code to confront the crisis brought on by the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Congress Launches Bipartisan Bill to Give Refugee Status to Certain Hong Kong Residents
summary: New bill is aimed at Hong Kongers at risk of persecution under Chinese territory's new national-security law. WASHINGTON-Lawmakers of both parties launched a bill to give refugee status to Hong Kong residents at risk of persecution under the Chinese territory's new national-security law, which local rights activists and many Western countries have decried as a tool for Beijing to suppress civil liberties in the semiautonomous city-state.

title: In Louisiana, a Fight Simmers Over Hitting Pause on Reopening
summary: Some in GOP want to end state of emergency and give local officials more power to reopen businesses after governor paused restart as coronavirus resurged. Some Republican lawmakers in Louisiana want to end the state's public-health emergency declaration over the coronavirus as a way to push back against Gov. John Bel Edwards's decision to pause the reopening process.

title: Second Chance at Aid for Small Businesses Draws Support
summary: Trump administration plans to work with Congress to steer remaining PPP funds to firms. WASHINGTON-The Trump administration and Congress are moving to give small firms a second chance for pandemic relief funds after the deadline to apply for forgivable loans passed Tuesday with about $130 billion in funds unclaimed.

title: Harvey Weinstein's Victims Entitled to Compensation From $19 Million Fund
summary: Insurance money is intended to compensate women who have accused former producer of sexual assault or harassment. Women who have accused Harvey Weinstein of sexual assault or say they were harassed while working at his former film studio will be entitled to payments from a nearly $19 million fund being created to compensate them, months after the former Hollywood producer was convicted of sex crimes.

title: Tribune Publishing in Talks to Give Hedge Fund Alden Global Another Board Seat
summary: Pact would extend Alden's standstill agreement with Tribune. Tribune Publishing Co. is in talks to add the co-founder of Alden Global Capital LLC to its board as part of an agreement that would prevent the hedge fund from making a hostile bid to buy the rest of the newspaper company in the near future, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Welcome to WSJ Noted.
summary: A news and culture magazine from The Wall Street Journal. Hello, and welcome to WSJ Noted. We're glad you're here.

title: Fauci Warns Coronavirus Cases Could Reach 100,000 a Day, as Surge Delays Reopenings
summary: With daily Covid-19 numbers growing across U.S., states shift gears on what is allowed. New coronavirus cases "could go up to 100,000 a day" if people continue to flout advice on social distancing and face masks, Anthony Fauci, the nation's top infectious-disease doctor told a Senate committee.

title: China's Security Law Tightens Vise on Hong Kong
summary: Western governments threaten repercussions following enactment of law that overrides the city's promised legal autonomy. HONG KONG-China rolled back the autonomy of Hong Kong's governance that's been in place since the city's handover from British colonial rule, with the imposition of a new law that gives Beijing a much stronger hand in policing the city and safeguarding its own authority.

title: Under 25 and Working? Social Distancing Might Not be Possible
summary: Fewer young people are working than ever before, but those with jobs often have to choose between risking their financial and personal well-being. In early April, Erin Payne drove to the group home in southwest Ohio where she cares for two men with serious disabilities. Normally, the 21-year-old would blare country music to keep her awake on her 40-minute commute. That day, she drove in silence.

title: Amazon Launches Space Push to Drive Cloud-Computing Growth
summary: AWS's move comes during a multiyear surge in U.S. military and civilian agency spending on space projects.

title: McGrath Defeats Booker in Kentucky Democratic Senate Primary
summary: Former Marine fighter pilot held off late surge from progressive state legislator and now faces Mitch McConnell in general election. Former Marine fighter pilot Amy McGrath won a Democratic primary to become the nominee for the U.S. Senate from Kentucky, fending off a strong late challenge from a state legislator whose rise to prominence reflected the renewed energy of the progressive movement.
